Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Voting, King said in an interview, gives “a little bit of your strength back and a little bit of your voice back. Being able to vote, being able to have a say in what happens in your society, in your state, is extremely important.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: an outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Restoring voting rights really is an issue where we’ve seen bipartisan momentum,” said Patrick Berry, counsel for the Democracy program at the Brennan Center.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: counsel for the Democracy program at the Brennan Center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: counsel for the Democracy program at the Brennan Center

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: More than 4.6 million people are disenfranchised in the United States because of felony convictions, according to the Sentencing Project, which studies the issue and advocates for restoration of voting rights for former felons.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: the Sentencing Project’s director of advocacy
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: the Sentencing Project’s director of advocacy

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: You’re civically dead and you can’t vote for the people who are levying those taxes,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: of Civic Nebraska, part of a large coalition of groups supporting the measure

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: At the time Nebraska was in step with other states. Now, while a few states require wait times for specific offenses or define completion of a sentence as including things such as fines and restitution, Nebraska is alone in requiring a general waiting period beyond imprisonment and release from parole or probation, said Margaret Love, co-founder and director of the Collateral Consequences Resource Center, which keeps a 50-state database on restoration of rights.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: co-founder and director of the Collateral Consequences Resource Center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: co-founder and director of the Collateral Consequences Resource Center, which keeps a 50-state database on restoration of rights

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “When people get out of our system, they’ve got to feel engaged in their community, and the number one way for a person to feel engaged in their community is to be able to vote for the leadership of that community,” he said.

“I do think that hopefully the waiting period reinforces the fact that voting is something very special, and hopefully that will be part of the things that an individual would consider if they’re tempted to break the law again,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: a member of the University of Nebraska Board of Regents
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a member of the University of Nebraska Board of Regents

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I felt so hopeless and helpless not being able to have my voice heard in this last election,” King said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: an outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: For the people she works with, being able to register to vote provides a sense of acceptance, especially when there are so many barriers on where they can live, jobs they can work and who they can associate with, she said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House, a safe house for women trying to reenter society

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “You can’t harm society by voting,” he said. “You can only help it.”

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: At least 14 states have introduced proposals this year focused on restoration of voting rights, according to the Brennan Center for Justice.
